[On looking at the photograph I have given 
of the <u>crossed callosal tract <\u> a source <s>hitherto <\s> 
of fallacy in all <s>our<\s> experiments upon the cerebral 
cortex and in deductions made from lesions of the 
cortex will be apparent. In the <s>ne<\s> brain 
of Man the <u>crossed callosal tract <\u> comprising 
the fibres from the one <s>opposite <\s> side <s>of the human brain <\s>
comes to lie in some parts within an eighth of 
of an inch of the cortex of the opposite side:
in some places it is absolutely closer. Now it is 
very difficult <s>almost impossible <\s> to destroy the gyrations of 
the cortex entirely without either directly or through sub-
sequent <s>dege <\s> inflammation influencing <s>those <\s>
the <u>crossed callosal <s>fibres <\s> tract <\u. Hence more or 
less of a bilateral <s>action <\s> function would thus be 
elicited. In the monkey dog or cat the crossed callosal 
fibres lie so close to the surface that I should 
consider it next to <s>almost <\s> impossible to destroy the cortex in 
its various depths without producing some effect upon 
<s>these <\s> them. <s>I<\s> At present I merely point this out in order
to show that without an extremely accurate know-
ledge of the course of the fibres in the brain 
<s>physiological <\s> experimental results & pathological 
deductions may be entirely misleading. In fact 
it is just a question whether electrical stimul-
ation of certain parts of the cortex producing a 
bilateral effect may not be <s>thus <\s> accounted 
for by the initiation being propagated to the <u>crossed callosal tract <\u>
